summary.seg: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.2.47 (hereafter Trinity MS O.2.47) is a small alchemical manuscript, the majority of which was copied by a single scribe. Part-way through the third quire, after the end of the Gloria mundi of Winandus de Rufo Clipeo (f. 45r), the scribe added a colophon: 'Completum et scriptum anno 1436 . 11 die aprilis' (Completed and written [on the] 11th day of April 1436). Like the Gloria mundi, the other two main texts in the volume - De secretis naturae of pseudo-Arnaldus de Villanova, and Rosarius minor of ?John of Garland (Hortulanus) - also commence at the beginning of their respective quires. As Pam Robinson (1988) noted, this suggests that they were each made as 'booklets' or codicological units: separately, but seemingly with the intention that they be bound together from the outset. The colophon may refer only to the completion of the Gloria mundi, therefore, but in all likelihood the other two were copied with it as part of a single campaign and close in date. Further texts were added subsequently, many by the same scribe, and in the space after the main texts, including the Gloria mundi, demonstrating that production extended beyond this date, too.

The short alchemical treatises and recipes are mostly in Latin and Middle English, but, unusually for an early 15th-century English manuscript, there are alchemical recipes in a dialect of Old Spanish, perhaps Catalan. These texts, which sometimes include Latin words, appear on ff. 32v, 35r, 50r and 50v. They appear to have been copied by the main scribe. One of the texts is attributed, perhaps spuriously, to the Spanish philosopher and polymath Ramon Llull, although Trinity MS O.2.47 is not recorded in the corpus of manuscripts currently known to preserve his works. Further research on these contents is required.

MS O.2.47 was extensively annotated by one of its former owners, John Dee (1527-1608) Dee, John, 1527-1608 , English mathematician and court astronomer of Queen Elizabeth I. Dee's signed the manuscript on f. 1r, and added titles, glosses, alchemical diagrams, and longer annotations to almost every leaf, and in more than one colour of ink, which suggests that he returned to the volume on several, separate occasions. The manuscript is recorded in Dee's 1583 library catalogue (now Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.4.20 , p. 154) where it is described as follows: 'Arnaldi de villa nova liber de Alchimia cujus initium est scito fili quod in hoc libro etc and cum alijs ejusdem opusculis . papyro 4o'. The Arnaldus de Villanova text to which Dee refers is the text at the opening of the manuscript on ff. 1r-6r.

Dee owned a large collection of manuscripts, many of which are now at Trinity College, including (with references in square brackets to J. Roberts and A.G. Watson's studies of Dee's library; see References for full citation):
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS B.15.20 , 'Jupiter marks' in upper margin of f. 1r [M63]
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.2.14 , Two Jupiter marks on f. 13r [DM3]
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.2.21 [DM3a]
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.2.33 , Dee marginal annotations throughout, ('trefoil' mark on f. i recto and 37r, are these also Dee marks?) [DM4]
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.2.47 , Dee's signature in the upper margin of f. 1r [M79]
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.2.50 [M3]
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.3.27 [M16]
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.4.20 (Dee's library catalogue) , Dee holograph [DM4a]
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.7.20 , according to Roberts and Watson, folios II:50r-62v are in Dee's hand, and other passages of text may also be in Dee's hand [DM5]
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.7.23 [M34]
Cambridge, Trinity College MS O.7.35 , selective table of contents in Dee's hand on f. xiv verso [M188]
Cambridge, Trinity College MS O.8.5 , according to Roberts and Watson, some of the marginalia are in Dee's hand, although they are cautious about M.R. James' identification of Dee as the scribe of the note in the upper margin of f. 186r, [DM6]
Cambridge, Trinity College MS O.8.9 , according to Roberts and Watson, title on f. 1r possibly in Dee's hand, some marginal annotations also possibly in Dee's hand [DM7]
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.8.28, ff. 1:1-25 , Dee added a title and his signature to f. [title page] recto; Dee's signature also on f. 25v, [DM8]
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.8.30 [M148]
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.9.39 [M54]
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.9.40 , according to Roberts and Watson, 'Liber primi finis' on f. 14r, and some of the marginalia are possibly in Dee's hand [DM9]
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.30 [M199]
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.38, ff. i-iv, 1-75 , according to Roberts and Watson the list on f. i recto is in Dee's hand, as is the text on f. iv verso and some of the marginal annotations on the later leaves [DM10]

msItem.title: De secretis naturae
msItem.author: pseudo-Arnaldus de Villanova (d. 1311)
msItem.rubric: 1r Incipit tractatus Arnaldi de villa noua de perfeccione operis alkimie qui quidem vocatur thesaurus secretus operacionum naturalium etc
msItem.incipit: 1r [S]Cito fili quod in hoc libro loquimur de secretis naturae et primo diuidam librum istum in .6. capitula , Primo diam quid est lapis
msItem.explicit: 6r .6to. dixi multiplicacionem lapidis et sic est finis . Deo gracias
msItem.finalRubric: 6r Explicit thesaurus secretus operacionem arnaldi de villa noua

note.p: Title added to upper margin of f. 1r in the hand of John Dee, 'Thesaurus Secretus'. Dee manicule on f. 2v and f. 3v. Dee 'monad' mark on f. 4r. Dee marginal annotations throughout. Dee refers to a 'Norton' in a note on f. 4r, this is almost certainly Thomas Norton, author of the alchemical poem Ordinal of Alchemy.
Excerpt from this text also in Cambridge, Gonville and Caius, MS 181/214 , p. 147.

listBibl.bibl: D.W. Singer, Catalogue of Latin and Vernacular Alchemical Manuscripts in Great Britain and Ireland: Dating from before the XVI Century (Brussels: Maurice Lamertin, 1928), no. 229.iii

A. Timmermann, 'Alchemy in Cambridge: An Annotated Catalogue of Alchemical Texts and Illustrations in Cambridge Repositories', Nuncius: Journal of the Material and Visual History of Science, 30.2 (2015), pp. 345–511

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.note:
Full transcription of medical recipe on f. 6r:
Recipe agrymoine .ma. j uel ij et fac bullire in aqua et vase terreo ... usque ad medietatem dem ß cola et que clarum est pone in vase viteo et quam volueris potare acc medietatem cisi de aqua illa et uitus pone succum duorum pomorum melangulorum et dem pota et fac sic bis uel ter et frangit petra et sanaberis

msItem.title: Miscellaneous medical and alchemical notes
msItem.incipit: 6v Item dicitur esse frigidum et siccum in .4to. gradu
msItem.explicit: 7r est elxir completum et mem istorum duorum extremitate est lapis noster
msItem.finalRubric: 7r est lapis nostri et cetera sit laus deo patris et ffilio

note.p: Title across upper margin of ff. 6v-7r in the hand of John Dee, 'Fragmentum egregium philosophirum. Marginal annotations by John Dee.
Text seems to be defective at the beginning.
Rubric in upper margin of f. 6v by main scribe does not appear to correspond to the text below.
Note that Timmerman treats the text(s) on ff. 6v-7r as one item.

msItem.title: Aquae plurimae
msItem.incipit: 7v Prima clauis est quod lapis noster sissoluitur per aquas plurimas
msItem.explicit: 8r Duodecima clauis est quod ponas illud in humare per .21. dies sub ventre equi Postea cum alembico in balneo marie distilles , Hoc facto custodi ipsum habes thesaurum incomparabilem vnum pondus supra infinitum , sciliced supra Mercurium

note.p: Title in upper margin of f. 7v by John Dee, 'Aquae plurimae'. Note in upper margin of f. 7v by John Dee 'Sanguis nostro Adami'. 'Monad' symbol in outer margin of f. 7v. Marginal notes throughout in Dee's hand. Dee alchemical calculation in blank portion of f. 8r. Note by Dee on this text in lower portion of f. 8r, 'This is an excellent fragment and worth the considering'.
'IHC' in the centre of the upper margin of f. 7v by the main scribe.

Similar text in Bologna, Biblioteca Universitaria, MS 952 (1444), ff. 153r-155r (where is attributed to 'magistrum Jacobum del borg St Saturnin'). The text in the Bologna MS is edited and discussed (in Spanish) by José Rodríguez Guerrero and Domingo Iglesias in Azogue 7, pp. 75-141.

msItem.incipit: 8v Recipe mercurius vna partem limature cupri tam limaturea vero lauatur cum aqua urine
msItem.explicit: 8v aquam predictam aluminis sic faciendo quasque iaceat in fundo vasis

msItem.title: Alchemical text
msItem.author: Pseudo-Albertus Magnus
msItem.incipit: 9r In dei nomine Amen Iam restat dicere et declarare de quod multis diebus abscondebatur , Et primo et principaliter est notandum quod mercurius noster non est mercurius Vulgi . nec communis mercurius
msItem.explicit: 10v Et hec est alteracio quarta ad alterandum eum ab humiditate inspissata calore ad lapidem calidum et siccum et durum frangibilem et fixum per calorem ignis communis et sicci

note.p: A longer version of this text with a slightly different preface also appears in Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.4.45, ff. 1:11r-1:12v ; in CUL MS Dd.4.45 the text has a final rubric indicating that the text was supposedly composed by Albertus Magnus, 'et ego Albertus dico', but Kibre assigns this text to pseudo-Albertus Magnus and Timmerman does not assign the text to a (pseudo-)author at all.
Marginalia by John Dee throughout.
Heavy bracketing around 9 lines of text in thick red-orange crayon on f. 10r, the bracketing accompanied by the numerals '24', probably glossing 'xxiiij' on the eighth line of bracketed-text.

msItem.title: Alchemical recipe for gilding iron or for removing the gilding from silver
msItem.rubric: 10v ffor to gylde ferro scilicet yronio for to filuer . hit make amalgam as þu woldist gilde
msItem.incipit: 10v Recipe j libram of alum de roche , and half a ponde of alfandida a quatron of abbo coporosa , and alle þese þynges be þey well j grounde and put in a pot glasyd and set it vpon þe fyre
msItem.explicit: 10v and wete cottoun þerinne and anoyte þerwith all þynges þat ben gylt , and anone þou mayste take of þy golde froo þe siluer

note.p: Annotations in the margin by the hand of the main scribe and of John Dee.

msItem.title: Alchemical text
msItem.incipit: 11r Be it remembryd that alle bodyes as well perfite as imperfite be made firste of þe .4. elementes þat is to sey fyre eyre erthe and water the whyche alle almyghty god mengyd coagulyd , and compilyd in pecis and þese .4. elementes ben þe priuyte of philosophers j hydd and whan þese .4. elementes be menged and joyned and chaunged from þer nature þey beth vertuos
msItem.explicit: 18r or oþer spirtus sol and lune the whyche engendryd by þis crafte excedyth naturally sol and lune in alle probacouns as well naturall as medicynall proieccyon moste be made in an erthyn crusyble before þe flyght of mercure and more sotyl þat þe medysn ys þe more perfyte and spefull it is amen Vnderstonde and I wylle þat ye knowe þat þe mater and þe sperme of alle metallis is mercure de cocte and made

note.p: 'IHC' title by the main scribe in the centre of the upper margin of f. 11r.
Simple drawing of alchemical vessels in the outer margin of f. 13v.
Marginal note by John Dee in the upper margin of f. 11r, and marginal notes throughout by him.
Unusual (?alchemical) symbol / monogram in the outer margin of f. 15v, a combination of the following characters: + h W.
The name/s 'isbell iohan' in the lower margin of f. 18r

Text ends abruptly, but M. R. James Catalogue and L. Mooney in IMEP 11 do not think the text is incomplete, instead that they think that the words following the 'amen' on f. 18r were meant to correct a lacuna in the text, but their place of insertion is unmarked.

Singer proposes that this text might be a Middle English partial adaptation of a Latin text sometimes known as the Breviloquium and variously attributed to 'Johannes Pauper' and 'Johannes Sawtre monachus de thorney'. See Singer for further information.

msItem.incipit: 19v Ad dandum bonum ingressum medicine super semper ponendum est
msItem.explicit: 19v quod sulfur coniunge cum medicina predicta . Aut jucera predicum sulfur cum oleo lune et fiet elixir per se

msItem.title: Rosarius minor
msItem.author: ?John of Garland (Hortulanus)
msItem.rubric: 20r Incipit Rosarius philosophie naturalis per ortolanum
msItem.incipit: 20r [Descendi in ortum meum ut videre plantas diuersorum inter flores retrum inueni rosam uineam seu alba et sanguineam seu rubeam dicoratam , eligi pulcherimam et inspexi quod idem ibi fuerunt pante et rare
msItem.explicit: 31r et fit elixir in tam quantum materia plusquam aurum uale et digestum et tinctum
msItem.finalRubric: 31r Explicit rosarius deo laus Ortolanj philosophi

note.p: A note 'per ortolanum' ('by Hortulanus') added to the rubric in a different ink, and perhaps by a different scribe (probably not John Dee).
Marginal annotations in the hand of John Dee throughout. Dee adds a final title to f. 31r 'Rosarius Minor impressus'.
It is not clear whether this text should be included among the true works by John of Garland, grammarian and philosopher active in England in the first half of the 13th century.

msItem.title: Alchemical recipe
msItem.incipit: 32r ffor to make sol of mars melt mars with azeruef ana in botum barbatum and after it is j molt , melt it ayen with as myche weyghte of fyne lune þerwith and breke þis siluer and whan þis lune is þus j broke melt it anoþer
msItem.explicit: 32r tyme with as myche more lune and it schal be teyned into color of sol and þe more þou meltis hit þer þe more it is worthe and þe more better by þe vertu of þe fyre

note.p: Marginal annotations by the hand of John Dee.
Not in IMEP.

msItem.title: Alchemical recipe to solder brass and add tin-plate to iron

note.p:
Full transcription:
ffor to sowde a plate of latoun to anoþer , Take pewter and roseyn and þerwith ye may sowde hem faste or yef ye wole tynne a þynge of yron , Take and melte yowr tyn in an yren panne and here yowre yron reed hoote . and anoynte hym well with rosyn and put it in þe tyn and take it out a noone by þe tone ende

msItem.rubric: 33v Of a werke of lune of man of almayn
msItem.incipit: 33v Recipe j part of lune fine of castilee , and three of partes of mercure viuo well j wayshe with salt comon grete and vinegre stronge
msItem.explicit: 34r and sulfur to make fine sol of mercure as it is a boue seyd of lune , deo gracias

msItem.title: Alchemical preparation of a capital to dissolve sublimed arsenic
msItem.rubric: 34r Thus is þe capitell j made þe whyche þat schall dissolue arsenicon sublymed
msItem.incipit: 34r Recipe sosa id est wodasshen .ij. pounds and calx virgyn vina .j. pound tartur j brent .j. pound of þis matters make þy capitell and boyle þe trydde part aweye of þe water and in þis capitel boyle thyn arsenyk vn to it be dissolued and þan drawe oute þe water by filter and put it to vapur vpon þe fire
msItem.explicit: 34r soft fire þere be houeþ to be in þy vaporacoun vn to þyn arsenyk be by hym sylf a lone , and þan take it oute and put it in a vessell of glas in a moyste place and it wole turne in to oyle , and þan joyne it with þe mater a boue seyd

note.p: Marginalia by the hand of John Dee.

msItem.title: Gloria mundi
msItem.author: Winandus de Rufo Clipeo
msItem.rubric: 36r Incipit prologus libri qui dicitur gloria mundi uel liber quinque clauum
msItem.incipit: 36r In nomine domini nostri ihesu christi et per uirtutem eius , Nominatur iste liber gloria mundi et lux solis , et liber luminum et liber quinque clauum et virtutum eet .v. est celestis
msItem.explicit: 45r Secundum enim viam illius gradus semper crudum berniaas addendum est , ut quartus rubeus docet gradus , cum suo pondere bernaas crudi Et hec dicta sufficiant
msItem.finalRubric: 45r Completum et scriptum anno 1436 11 die aprilis alide ter etcetera

note.p: Although this text is attributed to Arnaldus de Villa Nova in the manuscript, this text is now thought to be by Winandus de Rufo Clipeo.

Titles added in the upper margin of f. 36r in John Dee's hand, 'Arnaldus de Villa nova' and 'Liber quinque clauium'. Frequent marginal annotations by Dee throughout, including manicules and alchemical symbols.
Small marginal diagram of a flame ?in a sconce in the outer margin of ff. 38v and 39v.
Also in Oxford, Bodelian Library, MS Ashmole 1450 , ff. 18r-23v.

p.secFol: 2r: alumibus non est aurum seu argentum

support.material:
Paper, folded in octavo. Many leaves have partial watermarks visible, but due to the quality of the paper and staining to the leaves, watermark designs are not always possible to determine. The following leaves are given as case-studies. Folio 8 and folio 12: ?hand with cuff and ?star tethered to middle finger - measurements not possible as watermark is split across the gutter. Folios 8 and 12 are not a bifolium, but have the clearest 'halves' of the watermark design. This watermark seems to be present in all three quires. Resembles, but not the same as, Briquet 11152.
Folio 11a: unidentified partial watermark - measurements not possible as watermark is split across the gutter.

foliation.p: Foliation in use in this record: ?16th century foliation sequence of main leaves with later expansions and corrections
foliation.note: Folios 1-51 foliated in ink in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the upper outer corner of each recto in a ?16th century hand. The designation '11' was accidentally repeated by the original foliator and so a later foliation has redesignated the second of the two folio 11s as '11a'. The paper flyleaves at each end of the volume are unfoliated and so have been assigned the following designations within this record: ff. [i-iii] for the leaves at the front of the volume, and f. [iv] for the leaves at the end of the volume.

foliation.p: Foliated in ink in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the upper outer corner of each recto in a ?16th century hand. The designation '11' was accidentally repeated by the original foliator and so a later foliation has redesignated the second of the two folio 11s as '11a'.

supportDesc.condition: In fair condition. The edges of some leaves are slightly torn, generally without loss of text. Most leaves have minor damage from liquid stains and spills. Folio 51 ragged along top edge.

layout.seg: No visible ruling. Written in single-column format, typically 32 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Latin text written in an anglicana script with some secretary features. Double-compartment a. Loops on the ascenders of b, d, h, l. Long-s typically at the beginning of a word and 6-shaped-s typically at the end of the word. Descenders of f and long-s typically drop below the baseline.

Text in Middle English written in anglicana. Double-compartment a. Loops on b, h, and l. The letter r varies, it is sometimes 2-shaped, and at other times has an elongated minim that drops below the baseline. The letter w has an elongated middle minim.

decoNote.p: Small marginal diagram of alchemical vessels in the outer margin of f. 13v. Small marginal diagram of a ?candle in a candle-holder in the outer margin of f. 38v and f. 39v.

Infrequent flourished initials in the text ink; typically an enlarged majuscule letter 3-4 lines high with small decorative pen flourishes perhaps slightly influenced by 'cadels', see e.g., f. 48r 'E' in 'Elixir'.

note.p: Frequent marginal annotations in the hand of John Dee John Dee throughout the manuscript. Dee uses a thin pen and his hand has quite an elongated and narrow ductus, see e.g., empty space in the lower half of f. 8r, 'This is an excellent fragment and worth the considering'.

binding.p: Quarter-bound in ?tawed skin with paper sides over paste- or mill-boards. No raised bands on spine. Spine capped at head and tail by back-material, no headbands visible.
The alpha-numeric elements of the manuscript's current classmark ('O.2.47') are printed separately on three paper labels fixed to the spine with an adhesive.

Paper pastedowns at each end of the volume. The inside front cover contains the following:
The alpha-numeric elements of the manuscript's current classmark ('O.2.47') written in ink
A former classmark ('O.15.39') written in ink and struck through
A ?former classmark ('122.13.56' or '122.B.56') written in ink in the same hand as the current classmark, and struck through in red crayon

Three paper endleaves, ff. [i]- [iii] at the front of the volume and one paper endleaf at the rear of the volume, ff. iv at the rear of the volume; all paper endleaves probably contemporary with the binding. All paper endleaves blank.
Watermark on ff. [i] and [iv]: royal cypher - initials GR topped with a crown
Watermark on f. [ii]-[iii]: Dutch 'Maid of Dort' watermark - seated maiden holding spear with a hat dangling from the tip and lion rampant holding curved sword and sheaf of arrows within circular pallisade below the motto 'PRO PATRIA'.
Dimensions (L x W x D): 230 x 160 x 20 mm

origin.p: Date of production based on scribal colophon on f. 45r, 'Completum et scriptum anno 1436 11 die aprilis alide ter etcetera' (but see Summary and Robinson (1988) for further discussion). Place of production assigned based on palaeographical features.

provenance.p: Owned by John Dee (1527-1608) Dee, John, 1527-1608 , English mathematician and court astronomer of Queen Elizabeth I. Dee's name is present in the upper margin of f. 1r as 'Jo. Dee'. According to Roberts and Watson, Dee also added a title 'Thesaurus secretus' to the upper margin of f. 1r and extensive marginal annotations throughout the volume. The manuscript is recorded in John Dee's 1583 library cataloge (now Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.4.20 , p. 154) edited in Roberts and Watson John Dee's Library Catalogue where it has the siglum M79. J. Roberts and A. G. Watson, John Dee's Library Catalogue (1990), M79 and esp. p. 119

One of the manuscripts of Thomas Gale (?1635-1702) Gale, Thomas, 1635?-1702, dean of York, antiquary, Regius Professor of Greek at the University of Cambridge, and fellow of Trinity College Cambridge. This manuscript is listed among those in Gale's collection in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (1697).

listBibl.bibl: ODNB: Gale, Thomas (doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/10298)

provenance.p: One of the manuscripts of Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, antiquary and scholar, son of Thomas Gale. Roger Gale inherited the library of his father, Thomas Gale.

listBibl.bibl: ODNB: Gale, Roger (doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/10294)

history.acquisition: Donated to Trinity College by Thomas Gale Gale, Thomas (b. 1635/6, d. 1702), son of Roger Gale Gale, Roger (b. 1672, d. 1744), in 1738. The Gale donation is recorded in Cambridge, Trinity College MS Add. a/148 . Trinity College armorial bookplate with motto 'Collegium S.S. et Indiuiduae Trinitatis in Academia Cantabirgiensi' pasted at a rotated angle into the lower margin of f. 1r; 'Trinity College Library Cambridge' stamp in grey ink also present here. ODNB: Gale, Roger (doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/10294)
